answer_html: (Notice that \(x = \pm\sqrt{3}\) are not points in the domain and hence cannot be extrema or inflection points.)
answer_latex:
\textbf{(Notice that $x = \pm\sqrt{3}$ are not points in the domain and
hence cannot be extrema or inflection points.)}
hints_html: Remember that local extrema can only occur at the points in the domain where the derivative is zero or undefined and the function swaps from increasing to decreasing or vice versa. Inflection points are points in the domain where the second derivative is zero or undefined and the concavity changes.
hints_latex:
Remember that local extrema can only occur at the points in the domain
where the derivative is zero or undefined and the function swaps from
increasing to decreasing or vice versa. Inflection points are points in
the domain where the second derivative is zero or undefined and the
concavity changes.
hints_raw: Remember that local extrema can only occur at the points in the domain where the derivative is zero or undefined and the function swaps from increasing to decreasing or vice versa. Inflection points are points in the domain where the second derivative is zero or undefined and the concavity changes.
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
By part(a) and part(b) of this problem we see that the function changes from decreasing to increasing at \(x = -3\), so there is a local maximum there, and the function changes from decreasing to increasing at \(x = 3\), so there is a local minimum at x=3. The function changes concavity at \(x = 0\), so there is an inflection point at x = 0.

(Notice that \(x = \pm\sqrt{3}\) are not points in the domain and hence cannot be extrema or inflection points.)
sols_latex:
By
{part(a)}
and
{part(b)}
of this problem we see that the function changes from decreasing to
increasing at $x = -3$, so there is a local maximum there, and the
function changes from decreasing to increasing at $x = 3$, so there is a
local minimum at \emph{x=3}. The function changes concavity at $x = 0$,
so there is an inflection point at \emph{x = 0}.

\textbf{(Notice that $x = \pm\sqrt{3}$ are not points in the domain and
hence cannot be extrema or inflection points.)}
sols_raw:
By [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_2_(a)|part(a)]] and [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_2_(a)|part(b)]] of this problem we see that the function changes from decreasing to increasing at <math>x = -3</math>, so there is a local maximum there, and the function changes from decreasing to increasing at <math>x = 3</math>, so there is a local minimum at ''x=3''.  The function changes concavity at <math>x = 0</math>, so there is an inflection point at ''x = 0''.  


'''(Notice that <math> x = \pm\sqrt{3} </math> are not points in the domain and hence cannot be extrema or inflection points.)'''
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x)=\frac{2x^3}{3x^2-9}\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x)=\frac{2x^2(x^2-9)}{3(x^2-3)^2},\qquad{}f''(x)=\frac{4x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}\end{aligned}\]

Find the x coordinate of all local maxima, local minima, and inflection points. Be sure to indicate which is which.
statement_raw:
Consider the function

:<math>
f(x)=\frac{2x^3}{3x^2-9}
</math>

Its first and second derivatives are given by

:<math>
f'(x)=\frac{2x^2(x^2-9)}{3(x^2-3)^2},\qquad{}f''(x)=\frac{4x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}
</math>

Find the x coordinate of all local maxima, local minima, and inflection points.  Be sure to indicate which is which.
